title: Stranger danger reminder after incident in Orewa
text:
Stranger danger reminder after incident in Orewa Last updated 13:17, February 21 2017 Bevan Read 
A message has been emailed to parents asking parents to discuss safety guidelines with children walking or biking to school. 
A message has been sent to parents of children attending schools on Auckland's Hibiscus Coast warning of stranger danger. 
An incident where a vehicle appeared to follow an Orewa College student while they walked home around the Lakeside Drive, Grand Drive, Maire Road area on February 20, has been reported to police. 
Schools in the nearby vicinity of Orewa College were notified of the incident, and a message has been emailed to parents asking parents to discuss safety guidelines with children walking or biking to school. 
READ MORE: * Police praise pupils and community for action in Auckland's Northcote 
These are: 
- Walk or bike to and from school with a friend or two - you are less likely to be approached when in a group. 
- Walk or bike along busy routes where other people are present - don't use hidden tracks or areas that cannot be seen from the road. 
- Never get in a vehicle or go somewhere with someone you do not know - no matter what reason they give you. 
- Never accept any drink or food from a stranger - politely say no thank you and quickly move on and tell your parent or teacher about it. 
- If a person is persistent, follows you and won't leave you alone scream HELP, HELP, HELP as loudly as you can. Repeat this while getting as far away as possible. Ad Feedback 
- Ring 111 immediately if you are concerned for your safety or think someone is following you. 
This incident is the latest in a number of reported incidents of attempted child abduction near schools in west Auckland and on the North Shore. 
During the school holidays, a child was riding their bike on Princes St, Northcote Point, and was approached by two men in a white van with an orange and black strip. The child was asked whether they wanted to go with the men but the child's mother was just a few steps behind, according to Northcote Primary School's newsletter. Another incident was reported last week, but it turned out to be an innocuous offer of a ride to school. 
Police say there was nothing sinister behind the incident, when a man driving a van approached an 11-year-old boy near Northcote Intermediate on Wednesday morning. 
School principal Ben Kelsey said the man was a well-known member of the community, whose own children previously attended the school. 
The offer of a lift to the school was quite genuine, he said. - Rodney Times
